license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is Thing-a-Week #2, previous things can be found here. http://www.iheartrobotics.com/search/label/thing-a-week I don't know about you but I am tired of losing the key to the chuck.
Designed for attachment to a mini drill press. Optional magnet and thumb screw can improve the performance of this widget.

If you are using a Makerbot (No 90 degree overhangs) or if you don't need the magnet holder or thumbscrew you can edit the OpenSCAD file to disable these features. The STL file has both of these features included by default.
CA Glue and Kicker work well for gluing the magnet into place.
Print and enjoy.

author: LucidOne

print_settings.Notes:: print with the fan nozzle pointing up with supports from build plate only

description.text:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printrbot-play-fan-mount

VERSION 2:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1765343

I designed this to accommodate larger fans. I am using a 40x40x20mm part cooling fan and a 30x30x15mm hot end cooling fan. It mounts to tapped holes in the bottom of the extruder with three M3 screws. I used extra 6mm button head ones that came in my kit. To attach the fans, I used some craft wire and twisted the ends. You can also drill out the holes and use nuts and bolts if you want. I can now print beautiful 20 degree overhangs. 15 degree overhangs don't look too bad either. The ribbing prevents rotating air from coming out of the nozzle at and angle. Ducting to the hot end heat sink optimizes the air coming from the fan. An increased airflow fan here doesn't really make any difference. I am working on a wrap around duct to cool the part evenly, but space is tight.

Printer:

Printrbot play

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

print with the fan nozzle pointing up with supports from build plate only

title: Raspberry Pi Zero Version 1.3 Reference Model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is intended as a reference model of the Raspberry Pi Zero version 1.3 (the one with the camera connector).

Use this model in your 3d modeler of choice as a virtual place holder for the real thing. I've tried to be accurate enough that the first print off of a properly calibrated printer will fit a physical Raspberry Pi Zero. There are a number of capacitors that were not added to the model that are higher off of the PCB than the other components, so if you are using this to create an aluminum case that will be in contact with the Memory/CPU POP, have the contact extend down to it.

Comments appreciated.

Edit: Noticed that the crystal had some of it's surfaces deleted during saving in Sketchup. Modified it to be less detailed. features were sub millimeter in size so... The over all dimensions should be good enough for arranging clearance.

comments.text:
It would be great if you could export this in a "proper" format like .step or .iges.
Thanks :)
comments.author: Nicolinux

comments.text: Tried to convert it from .skp to .iges and .step.  Sketchup freeware has a collada export, FreeCAD has a collada import and both .step and .iges export.  Fusion 360 has the ability to open .step files, and 123D has the ability to open .iges files.  FreeCAD was able to read the Sketchup collada file, but the exports from FreeCAD looked to be empty when opened in 123D and Fusion 360.  As such I am reluctant to attach the files as I cannot confirm that they are useful.  If anyone is interested, I may consider posting the collada file after coloring and maybe naming the various meshes.
comments.author: Nicolinux

comments.text: Yep, I went the same route as you did. Imported .dae fine in FreeCAD but wouldn't export .step or .iges properly. File size is at 4KB which is a good indicator that it failed.
comments.author: Anathae

comments.text: I think I see what the problem is... the .dae file created by sketchup is a collection of meshes, Fusion 360 and 123D are expecting solids in the .step or .iges files.  Looks like the various meshes would have to be converted to solids (if they can) before exporting as a .step or a .iges file.  This is looking like alot of work.
comments.author: Nicolinux

comments.text: I am using the free versions of Sketchup 2015 and 2016 and it doesn't have an export ability as .step or .iges. files.  I have access to Fusion 360, Autodesk 123D as well as FreeCAD so I'll take a quick look as to what I can convert it too.

description.text: my first desing and printing. is a protector for remot controll DEA of two bottons.

This afternoon I heard my wife cursing in the kitchen. When I asked her what was wrong, she told me that her little Toastmaster Mini-Chopper (Model 1122) had lost two of it's feet - making it wobble like crazy. I pulled off one of the two remaining feet, spent 5 minutes on ShapeSmith, 5 more in Replicator and 20 minutes printing them on my Thing-O-Matic. Now it sits on the counter solid as a rock - although I'm printing two more, just for cosmetic reasons…

Stand up paddleboard handle that attaches to a kayak paddle, for the days I'd rather spend most of my time sitting.

There are two different versions of the smaller clamping part, one uses M5 brass inserts* (ebay affiliate link), the other uses standard M5 lock nuts. It also uses 25mm M5 Button Cap Screws. (I didn't have the right type of screw on hand so I used the regular socket cap version)

title: MAC PRO ENCLOSURE TO HOLD MAC MINI

description.text:
Hi All, I have always wanted to make a mac pro in miniature.

In fact I made one before so I could put a dvd burner inside
(see here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:688986)

This one however houses an old school mac mini.
I think is fantastic!
And if you have a mac mini I hope you do aswell.

The mac mini fits nice and snuggly! if it gets too hot inside I guess you could cut a hole underneath it that no one will see or place a usb powered fan, up to you.

BTW, the main part is 190mm tall in case you have the room to print it in one piece.
I dont know what that is in inches (its time you guys join the rest of the world and join the metric system).
It is 560grams in weight but it did have two tiny little side pieces as scafolding (no more than 25 grams I'd say).

Please print it and share the photo

Printer Brand:

3D Systems

Printer:

CubePro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

IT NEEDS SUPPORT TO CREATE THE HOLE FOR THE DVD SLOT AND ALSO FOR THE MAIN PART.
ITS MINIMAL THOUGH AS LONG AS YOU PRINT IT IN THE DIRECTION THAT I HAVE PLACED THEM ON

how i model it (how accurate it is)

Hi its pretty accurate!
I model it based on a PDF I found with its dimensions then I shrunk it in proportion once i had it modelled.
I did however made the handles a bit more chunkier

Add a usb port anywhere.Surprised I couldn't find an stl available.
A little electronics knowledge is needed to find where and how to tap the DC voltage to power the usb port.
ALWAYS unplug before anything.

I'm not going to detail every step involved as I'm sure your requirements are not going to be identical to mine.
If you don't get it ...maybe you shouldn't be doing it.You CAN get hurt,burn your house down.....

Included is a marking template for the mounting holes.

The pictures detail an old 2.1 PC speaker system and Android phone,with a bad battery,repurposed to an internet radio/DLNA audio receiver that now,only needs one plug in my power strip.

Printer:

CR-7

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

20% any

The usb cutout should be pretty tight to avoid the glue from seeping out.
It will probably need some finishing to fit the face of the connector properly
Simple FreeCad design

Presented as "Proof of concept"

Tape around the connector or the hot glue will ooze inside the connector.
Fit the connector flush with the front of the panel.
Fill the space around the connector with hot glue.
Find yourself points on the board to supply power to the dc-dc regulator or wire an old 5 volt adapter to the mains voltage and wire the 5 volt output directly to the female usb.
ALWAYS unplug before anything.Make sure all mains connections are well insulated.
Adjust the regulator pot for 5 volts,I always try to stay around 5.1 volts.I actually have a couple devices that will not charge below that.

If your SURE the device can supply 2A more,the center two pins can be shorted together to trigger high speed charging.
I probably should add a separate fuse.

If you don't get it ...maybe you shouldn't be doing it.You CAN get hurt,burn your house down.....

LASTLY....DON'T BLAME ME,I'M JUST PUTTIN IT OUT THERE.

A door handle to freshen up my 1980s bedroom wardrobe. Curved and comfortable to use.
Fully parametric and prints in one piece without any raft or support material.

Modify the OpenSCAD constants to match your requirements:
  • - The gap between the bolt holes
  • - The screw hole radius (current set to fit M5 bolts)
  • - The counter-sink screw head depth
  • - The bolt length
    • The defaults are based on a 108mm hole-spacing (?), 15mm thick door, and a 50mm length bolt. The model adjusts itself so the nut is flush with the end of the bolt. If you want the handle to be less proud, use 45mm or 40mm bolts. Print without raft or support material then screw the bolt into the counter-sunk hole and through to the door. Secure with a nut and optional washer if the door material is particularly soft.

author: Riley3999

description.text:
The T-45 Goshawk is a highly modified version of the BAe Hawk. Manufactured by McDonnell Douglas (now Boeing) and British Aerospace (now BAE Systems), the T-45 is used by the United States Navy as their primary jet trainer. It is flown by student NFOs in the advanced strike pipeline at Training Wing 6 in Pensacola, FL.

This model was interesting in that I had detailed blueprints (off of Google as usual) of the original BAe Hawk, yet none of the T-45 plans or schematics. In order to account for all of the design changes by Boeing and BAe to make it carrier worthy, I had to constantly jump back and forth between the very high-quality photos of the Goshawk and the plans for the BAe Hawk. I look forward to flying this bird in the future and I hope you enjoy it in your home.

Version 1.0.9

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm High Resolution

Infill:

10% 0.4mm Diamond (fast)
The orthographic three-view I used as the primary reference. In spite of the fact that this photo is the original Hawk, I was able to capture most of the design changes in the following photos.

comments.text:
Greetings,
After 19hrs this was the end result. This is my 3rd attempt at this print, 1st was T45.stl scaled down, 2nd was T45all.stl scaled down and this T45all.stl full scale. Each time I had issue with the left horizontal stabilizer and the intake pods on the fuselage, I noticed in my slicer Simplify3d after the print that there is a space between the intake and the fuse (see capture).
I printed @ 1.5mm resolution and 8% infill with PLA+. I am new to 3D printing so it could be my fault, but I have had successful prints before and after these attempts. Any advice would be welcome.
Thank you

title: Volume of Buildings on a Street

description.text: This is a project for geometry students to learn through discovery by building composite figures to look like a street.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard

Infill:

use a low infill for prototyping

Notes:

Use a low infill for prototyping then a higher infill percentage for the final version.

I made a level plane (street) for the composite figures (buildings) to sit upon.
Then I created the composite figures by combining more than one shape so that we could have buildings.
I created five different buildings with all different dimensions, then recorded the length, width, and height and/or radius to determine the volume of each building.

Overview & Background:

  • Enhancing knowledge of area and volume of several figures and composite figures through the use of technology.

Objectives: Students will be able to:

  • Solve real life problems utilizing volume of composite geometric figures.
  • Create their own 3-dimensional “block” using composite geometric figures.

Audiences: Geometry Common Core Students

Subjects: Math, Technology, Art, Computer Graphics

Skills Learned (Standards):

  • G.GMD.3: Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems.
  • G.MG.1: Use geometric shapes, their measures, and their properties to describe objects (e.g., modeling a tree trunk or a human torso as a cylinder).

Lesson/Activity:

  • Anticipatory Set:
    1) Students will look at an image of a house provided on the front board.
    a. Question: Describe the house using 3-dimensional figures.
    2) Students will look at an image of the Empire State Building on the front board.
    a. Question: Describe the Empire State Building using 3-dimensional figures.

Definition: A composite geometric figure consists of two or more 3-dimensional figures. For example: a table is a composite geometric figure of two or more different sized rectangular prisms.

Procedure:

1) Students will focus on the model provided by the teacher. The teacher will display the “buildings on a street” that were made of composite geometric figures.

2) Teacher will describe how they made the model using tinkercad (see how I designed this section) and give a brief tutorial on how to use tinkercad.

3) Students will be instructed to create 5 composite geometric figures in groups (buildings).

4) Once students have created these figures, they will use the dimensions in tinkercad to calculate the volume of each composite figure by finding the volume of each geometric figure and add their measures together.

5) Students will type up the volumes and print their creations using a 3D printers.

6) Students will then work in partners on the provided handout to reinforce their knowledge of calculating the volume of composite geometric figures

Duration: One Lesson Period (Approximately 42 Minutes)

Preparation:

Prior Knowledge: Students Should Already Know:

  • The identifications of 3-dimensional figures, such as; a sphere, hemisphere, cylinder, hemi-cylinder, cone, cube, rectangular prism, and square based pyramid.
  • How to calculate the volume of several 3-dimensional figures, such as; a sphere, hemisphere, cylinder, hemi-cylinder, cone, cube, rectangular prism, and square based pyramid.

Technology/Resources Prerequisites:

  • Access to a computer
  • Create a tinkercad account
  • Create new design

Rubric & Assessment: A possible rubric for grading is below

  • (10 points) Students followed the rules for constructing their figures.
  • (50 points, 10 points per figure) The equations and calculations for each 3-dimensional figure are written and accurate.
  • (10 points) Neat and organized presentation of the design.
  • (10 points) Students answered worksheet questions correctly.
  • (20 points) Students participated in group work and class discussions.

Handouts: Homework will consist of a worksheet to reinforce the concepts learned in today’s lesson.

In this activity, students will create three-dimensional cones in order to discover the formula for the volume. Students will be given specific dimensions to use in order to create their 3-D shape in the Tinkercad program. Groups will be assigned to students so that they are not working alone.

Team Members: Jennifer Silhan, Leanne DiGiovanna, Jordan Federico

Project: Volume of a Cone

Overview and Background: As students complete this project they will use critical thinking skills in order to discover the formula for finding the volume of a cone. Students will learn how to use the program called Tinkercad and will better their skills with working with their classmates.

Objectives: Students will be able to:

  • calculate the volume of a cone
  • discover the formula for finding the volume of a cone
  • use the definition of a radius and a diameter to find the volume of a cone
  • create all of these cones in Tinkercad with the specific dimensions given

Audiences:

-grade: 8th grade mathematics
-age: 13-14 years old
-skill level: general education / inclusion / honors

Subjects: Relevant subjects include:

-math
-drawing and design (graphic design)

Skills Learned (NYS Common Core Standards):

  • CCSS.Math.Content.8.G.C.9 :Know the formulas for the volumes of cones, cylinders, and
    spheres and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

  • Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving volume of cylinders, cones, and spheres.

Lesson/ Activity:

  1. Log in to your Tinkercad account. If you do not have an account yet, create one now.

  2. Under the tab that says "Project" choose "Create Project."

  3. Click on the blue tab that says " Create New Design."

  4. On the top left of the page, click on the "Design" tab.

  5. Then select the option labeled "Properties."

  6. Under "Name" create a new title as " Discovery of a Cone."

  7. On the right hand side of the window page, locate the "Geometric" tab.

  8. Choose the cone and drag it into the "workplane."

  9. Get familiar with all of the Tinkercad tools.

  10. Once you feel comfortable, create two cones with the information provided.

  11. The first cone that you will create will have the following dimensions: an altitude of 18mm, and a diameter of 20mm.

  12. The second cone that you will create will have the following dimensions: an altitude of 8mm, and a diameter of 26mm.

  13. For the third cone, you will choose an altitude and diameter.

  14. Save these files as an "STL" file.

  15. After you have created these images you will be required to print these cones out in your 3-D printer.

  16. Use your manipulatives to assist you in discovering the volume formula for the cones you have created. (hint: The formula will remain the same for EVERY cone you've created.)

  17. Make sure to show all of your work on a separate sheet of paper.

  18. HAVE FUN! :]
Image 1: Cone with altitude of 18mm and a diameter of 20 mm. Image 2: Cone with altitude of 8mm and a diameter of 26 mm. Image 3: Cone with altitude of 22mm and a diameter of 12mm.

Duration: This project should take approximately 2 class periods. If not completed, students can have one extra day.

Preparation: The students should either be in a computer lab, library, or in the every day classroom with a laptop cart provided. Students should already the difference between radius and diameter, and should be able to find one of them if given the other. Students should also be provided with the handout and a calculator.

References: There is no pre or post research students or teachers have to complete. This is a discovery lesson where students are required to determine the volume of a cone.

Rubric & Assessment: Attached is the rubric a teacher would use to assess this project.

Rubric

title: Kossel Mechanical + Magnetic Ball joint effector and carriage

description.text: I don't think I am the only one who experienced "flying" magnetic effector. I search the web and only found comments on the strength of the magnet. I've also added a "safety belt" like this - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RM1ytIyH6BQ, but it only decrease the severity of the disaster. I think it can be completely avoid only if the strength of the magnet is greater than the force of the stepper motor. However, it may then drastically reduce the life of the magnet due to friction, I think. Therefore, I design a combination of mechanical and magnetic ball joint.

Printer:

MicroMake

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Infill:

75

The metallic ball is surrounded by the plastic more than a half by a little bit. You need to press it in with force. It can hold the arms even without the magnets. By adding the magnets, it then becomes zero back lash mechanism. With such structure, the effector will not "fly away" and the requirement of the magnet will not be so stringent. It is my first design with FreeCAD. Any comments are welcome.

Bill of Materials:

  1. Metallic Ball x 12
  2. Carbon fibre arms x 6
  3. Countersink magnet M12x3

title: Cross Section of a Right Rectangular Prism

description.text: For this lesson students will be learning how to take the cross sections of right rectangular prisms. This lesson involves a lot of visualization, so having the kids create their own right rectangular prisms allows them to have a more hands on experience, allowing them to grasp a better understanding of the content. Students will learn to take the cross section that is either parallel or perpendicular to the base.

When designing the right rectangular prisms I made sure to create a before and after figure so that it is easier to see the differences when taking the cross section. One big tip is to create a rectangular hole (cross section) that is bigger than the actual prism, this way the hole appears through the entire figure.

Overview/ Background

Once students have completed this project they will be able to understand the visual component to this lesson. They will be able to see how the cross section of a right rectangular prism can change depending on whether it is perpendicular or parallel to the base. Students will also have a better understanding of what it means to be parallel or perpendicular to an object.

Objectives

Students will be able to understand how to take the cross section that is parallel to the base of a right rectangular prism.
Students will be able to understand how to take the cross section that is perpendicular to the base of a right rectangular prism.

Audiences

7th Grade
Ages 11 - 13

Subjects

Mathematics
Architecture

Skills Learned (CCLS)

Describe the two-dimensional figures that result from slicing three-dimensional figures, as in
plane sections of right rectangular prisms and right rectangular pyramids.

Lesson/Activity

Step 1: (15 mins) Direct Instruction: Go over what a cross section is and what it means to be parallel an perpendicular. Then show students what a right rectangular prism is.
Step 2: (5 mins) Go over instructions with students.

  1. Make sure all students have created an account on Tinkercad.
  2. Show how to create a right rectangular prism on Tinkercad.
  3. Show how to create a cross section (Hole) onto the right rectangular prism.
  4. Ask if any students have any questions about how to use the program.
    Step 3: (25 mins) Students work with a partner to create their own right rectangular prisms.
    Make sure to circulate through the classroom to make sure that students are staying on task and understand how to use the program.

Duration

This project should take students approximately one class (45 mins each)
15 mins: Direct Instruction - Explain what cross sections are and how to take the cross section of a right rectangular prism.
5 mins: Explain what the activity entails and show example.
25 mins: Have students work with partners and create their own cross sections.

Preparation

This lesson entails the use of a computer lab or Chromebooks (whatever is available at your school). Make sure to reserve a spot in the computer lab in advance! For HW the day before have students create an account on Tinkercad, that way they are ready to create their project.

Rubric and Assessment

Grade students based off of the following:

  1. How well they worked with their partner.
  2. Did they create a before and after 3D figure?
  3. Do they have a cross section that is both parallel and perpendicular to the base?
  4. How well they stayed on task.
  5. Are their cross sections accurate?

description.text: Students are required to make two dice, one fair and one unfair. When the dice are printed, students will then perform an experiment in which they roll the dice separately a certain amount of times and keep a tally chart of numbers that appear. Students then compare the theoretical and experimental probabilities and draw a conclusion at the end.

Step 1

Go to symbols tab and click on "DICE". Drag the item to the middle of the grid

step 2

You will Make a die with numbers 1-6. This will be the fair die. Make sure you make the numbers mesh with the die block, click on hole button, Then click the group button to make sure the number has been indented into the die.

step 3

You will make a second die. This die will be unfair so make sure you have numbers that repeat on the faces of the die. You will follow the same procedure as step 2!!!

overview and background

1) Students will need to figure out theoretical probabilities using both fair and unfair dice. Examples will include: probability of one number on fair die, probability of one number on unfair die, and probability of even number or odd number.

2) Students will also compare and contrast theoretical probabilities with experimental probabilities.

Objectives

Students will be able to:
Define theoretical probability
Define experimental probability
compare and contrast theoretical and experimental probabilities
apply theoretical and experimental probabilities

Audiences

This thing is set for grades 7-8

Subjects

Mathematics
Probability

Skills learned

CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.7.SP.C.5
Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around 1/2 indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.7.SP.C.6
Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run relative frequency, and predict the approximate relative frequency given the probability. For example, when rolling a number cube 600 times, predict that a 3 or 6 would be rolled roughly 200 times, but probably not exactly 200 times.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.7.SP.C.7
Develop a probability model and use it to find probabilities of events. Compare probabilities from a model to observed frequencies; if the agreement is not good, explain possible sources of the discrepancy.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.7.SP.C.7.A
Develop a uniform probability model by assigning equal probability to all outcomes, and use the model to determine probabilities of events. For example, if a student is selected at random from a class, find the probability that Jane will be selected and the probability that a girl will be selected.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.7.SP.C.7.B
Develop a probability model (which may not be uniform) by observing frequencies in data generated from a chance process. For example, find the approximate probability that a spinning penny will land heads up or that a tossed paper cup will land open-end down. Do the outcomes for the spinning penny appear to be equally likely based on the observed frequencies?

Lesson/Activity

Step 1) Students will be asked to find a theoretical probability of an event using their dice.
Step 2) Students will then roll their Dice a certain number of times and keep a tally of how many times a number has appeared.
Step 3) students will then answer questions about their comparison of not probabilities

Duration

This project will be approximately 30 minutes long

Preparation

Students should know the definition and application to theoretical and experimental probabilities
Students should know how to find the probability of an event.
Students will need a fair die
Students will need an unfair die

By: Michelle Lorentzen, Ariana Wanderlingh, Kevin Valenza

This project is an introduction to conic sections. The four conic sections are: circles, parabolas, hyperbolas, and ellipses. This is to show how they are formed by cutting either a single or double cone with a plane.

How we designed this

For the circle, we started with the cone and the letter "I" and spread it out to look like a plane. For the ellipse, we did the exact same thing, but angled the plane to create an ellipse. For the parabola, start with the cone and a plane where the plane passes through the base of the cone. For the hyperbola, we started with a cone then duplicate the same cone and rotate it 180 degrees and move it up. Then take a plane and cut the double cone to create the hyperbola.

Overview & Background

By completing this project, students will learn how the four different conic sections are formed by cutting either a cone or a double cone with a plane. They will learn how they are formed: hyperbola is a double cone where circles, parabolas, and ellipses are single cones.

Objectives

Students will learn:

  1. How to cut a cone with a plane
  2. What is formed after cutting a cone with a plane
  3. What the difference between the four conic sections are
Audience

Grade: 10th, 11th, and 12th
Age: 16 - 18
Skill Level: Geometry & Pre-Calculus

Subjects

Math and Physics

Students derived the equations of ellipses and hyperbolas given the foci. That from Geometry will lead into conic sections. From seeing these formulas, they will now be able to see where they come from, which is the conic sections. Later on in Pre-Calculus and Physics, the students will be learning the formulas for all of the conic sections.

Standards

CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSG.GPE.A3

Based off the design of the district's Pre-Calculus curriculum.

Lesson/Activity

Steps:

  1. Explain the four different conic sections

  2. Get with assigned partners

  3. Create an account on tinkercad.com

  4. Create the four conic sections

  5. Complete the worksheet
Duration

10 minutes - Explaining what conic sections are

20 minutes - Let the students create the conic sections with a partner on Tinkercad

10 minutes - Class Discussion to get ideas on how they created their conic sections

Preparation

Students need to know what circles, parabolas, hyperbolas, and ellipses look like. Students will use Tinkercad to complete the activity.

References

If students are unfamiliar with the conic sections, refer to the link below to further understand each section.

https://www.khanacademy.org/math/precalculus/conics-precalc

Post research - Create the worksheet

Rubric & Assessment

The students will have to save the link to their conic sections and send us the link. The students will complete a handout based on the activity they just completed. We will grade it on a scale of 1 - 4, not based off of correctness, but on effort.

Handouts

Date:__
Period:_____
Conic Sections

  1. What are the four conic sections?
    a.
    b.
    c.
    d.

  2. How are each of the four sections cut?
    a.
    b.
    c.
    d.

  3. How did you use tinkercad.com to create the four conic sections?

  4. What did you learn from this activity?

description.text: In this lesson, students will be using the 3D software, Tinkercad.com, to create their very own composite figure. Students will be creating a shape with a hole in the center and will be using their prior knowledge of volume of 3D figures to find the volume of the solid.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard

Infill:

Use a low infill for prototyping

Tips

Ensure that when students are creating two shapes, the "hole" will go completely through the solid figure they have created.
In order for students to see the hole clearly, have students use a shape that goes completely through the solid by having the hole be the same height as the solid.

Overview and Background

In completing this project, students will learn how to use technology to create three dimensional figures as well as finding volumes of composite figures.

Objectives

Use the volume formulas of three dimensional figures to come up with the volume of composite figures.

Audience

Grade 8, ages 13-14.

Subjects

In this lesson, we will be using math, art, and technology.

Skills Learned (Standards)

CCSS.Math.Content.8.G.C.9
Know the formulas for the volumes of cones, cylinders, and spheres and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

Lesson and Activity

Go to Tinkercad.com and log in using your user name and password from yesterday’s class. Create a new project and label it with your name.
Step one: Pick two three dimensional figures. Make the smaller figure a “hole” and place it inside the other. Make sure you are putting a smaller shape inside of the bigger shape. Group these figures together to form your composite shape. Draw out you composite figure in the space below.
Step two: Draw out the two figures that create your composite figure and label each with the dimensions that you see on your screen.
Step three: Find the volume of each of the shapes above that formed your composite figure. Make sure you are using the correct volume formulas for each shape!
Step four: We want to know the volume of our solid figure. In order to do this, what will we be doing with the two volumes we found in the last step?
Find the volume of the composite shape you created on your screen.
Step five: Print out your figure using the 3D printer and complete the practice below.

Duration

This activity is designed for a 40 minute class period.

Preperation

Students should already be familiar with using Tinkercad.com. Also, students should know how to find the volume of three dimensional figures as well as volume of composite figures.

Rubric and Assessment

Students will be assessed on participation; ensuring that students are completing what must get done in class.
The next day, I will collect the worksheets students were completing in class.
Students will receive a grade on how they did on the worksheet.
Each section is worth 10 pts for a total of 50pts.

Handouts

Attached is the handout that students will use to record their work.

For this project, students are to create their own train car using the following shapes: cylinder, rectangular prism and cone. After creating the train car, students will calculate different units of measurement using the volumes of the various shapes!

Instructions

Create one cylinder, of any dimensions you choose, that will serve as the train's wheels. Make sure to rotate the wheel so it is lying just like an actual train wheel on the track. Clone the original cylinder three times to make sure the four wheels are all of equal size. Next, align your four wheels so they all lie straight on the track.

Now it is time to create the train car. Drag a box onto the screen and choose the dimensions to your liking. The four wheels should to the train car at the appropriate sides. The train car should also be raised above ground level so it does not drag.

The final piece of the train is the train horn. To create this, drag another cylinder and cone onto the plane. The cylinder should lie ON TOP of the train car, so that it is coming out of the top of the box. The cone should then be placed on top of the cylinder to form the horn shape. Once again, choose the dimensions of your liking that is reasonable.

Choo Choo!!

Project: Train Car

Overview & Background: By completing the project, students will see the real-world application of the figures they are studying in geometry. Also, students will be calculating their own unique volumes for various shapes, reinforcing their procedural fluency.

Objectives: After completing this train car project, students will be able to:
1.) Calculate volume and surface area of given shapes.
2.) Use geometry shapes to create real-world objects.
3.) How to create a 3-D model of a train car.
4.) Compare and contrast which shapes should be placed together to create certain objects.

Audiences: This lesson is designed for high students in geometry.

Subjects: math, art, science

Standards: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSG.GMD.A.1
Give an informal argument for the formulas for the circumference of a circle, area of a circle, volume of a cylinder, pyramid, and cone. Use dissection arguments, Cavalieri's principle, and informal limit arguments.

CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSG.GMD.A.3
Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems.

Lesson/Activity:

STEP 1: Create one cylinder, of any dimensions you choose, that will serve as the train's wheels. Make sure to rotate the wheel so it is lying just like an actual train wheel on the track. Clone the original cylinder three times to make sure the four wheels are all of equal size. Next, align your four wheels so they all lie straight on the track.

Step 2: Now it is time to create the train car. Drag a box onto the screen and choose the dimensions to your liking. The four wheels should to the train car at the appropriate sides. The train car should also be raised above ground level so it does not drag.

Step 3 and Step 4: The final piece of the train is the train horn. To create this, drag another cylinder and cone onto the plane. The cylinder should lie ON TOP of the train car, so that it is coming out of the top of the box. The cone should then be placed on top of the cylinder to form the horn shape. Once again, choose the dimensions of your liking that is reasonable.

Duration: Two class periods. One period for creating train and the second period for calculations.

Preparation: Students need to know how to calculate volume of 3-D shapes.

References: Tinkercad software https://www.tinkercad.com/

Video for students to watch on composite shapes (for the horn of the train)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vqoTudvn5rA

Webpage on volume formulas
http://www.math.com/tables/geometry/volumes.htm

Rubric and Assessment: By the end of this project, students will have used their knowledge of 3-D shapes and geometry to calculate the volume and surfaces of real-world applications. First, they will create a train car using different figures in Tinkercad. Finally, they will complete a worksheet on volume and surface areas related to their specific train car's dimensions.
A possible rubric for grading:
(30 points) Students followed rules and instructions for creating the train
(10 points) Realistic and reasonable dimensions
(10 points) Creativity
(40 points) Successful completion of the worksheet on volume. This includes correct solutions based on their dimensions.
(10 points) Class participation.

Handouts: The students worksheet is attached.

title: Mini Cooper With Wheels FIXED Rear Axle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to 3D print a Mini Cooper but found no models on Thingiverse. Finding a model was quite challenging, but after a while of digging I found a video game that offered a few 3D models to show how good they were. I was able to download them, and after a series of conversions and a lot of software, primarily Meshmixer, I was able to separate what I wanted from the wheels and the body. I had to decrease the resolution a bit because it was over 300,000 triangles, the maximum for Tinkercad, but I did it in unimportant spots. Then I simplified the wheels, and made an axle system that should work fine. I made the bottom flat so it could print, so part of the bumper is gone.

You may need to scale it down for your printer but the axle should still work, there is a lot of clearance. I will print it ASAP and post some pictures, please try it out for yourself.

Print the car, Repetier shows it will take around 4 hours (I will print it once I get my heated bed working), then print 2 of the wheels, and 2 of the wheels with axle. Assembly is simple, just slide the axle through the car and glue to to the other wheel, it will probably not hold from friction. I printed one a set of wheels (one with axle and one without) and that took 45 minutes, so 90 minutes to print all 4. Once that is assembled, the rear axle may fall through the car, you can see what I mean in the picture. That is what the bottom thing is for. Glue that to the bottom of the car on the rear axle, and then the axle should be able to slide in easily but not fall out. This piece took about 10 minutes. Use supports when printing the car, and no supports with the wheels.

I uploaded a file that has a fixed right mirror, it gave a manifold warning so i'll keep the original up as well.

title: 74th Pennsylvania Infantry Monument - Gettysburg, Pennsylvania
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The monument to the 74th Pennsylvania Infantry is a rarity in Civil War statuary, depicting not a fighting soldier or a marching soldier, but one in the throes of death. In a pose based on the popular "Dying Gaul," a widely reproduced Roman statue popular in the late 18th to mid-19th century, the color sergeant slumps to the ground mortally wounded.

The monument was dedicated on July 2nd, 1888. In 2003, it was struck by an SUV and shattered into multiple pieces. Since restored, it stands on Howard Avenue on the 11th Corps' line of battle north of Gettysburg.

title: Primbal - 3D Printed 3-Axis Brushless Camera Gimbal for XiaomiYi/GoPro

description.text:
Finally a 3-axis gimbal designed exclusively for 3D printing! This gimbal is composed of 23 printed parts that are all printer friendly. All three axis are fully adjustable to perfectly balance the gimbal.

This gimbal is designed with focus on mounting a Xiaomi Yi to a TBS Discovery frame, but it can be used wherever you like and with GoPros as well (see special GoPro STLs). Included in are STLs for a longer yaw arm which will allow for full rotation on the roll axis. Otherwise the roll axis is limited to about 45 degrees which is good for most use.

Specs:
Parts: 23 Printed
Hardware: 4 x M1 Bolt and Nut 12mm, 6 x M2 Bolt 8mm, 4 x M3 Bolt 4mm, 2 x M3 Bolt 6mm
Motors: 1 x Turnigy 2804-210kv, 2 x Turnigy 2206-140kv
Controller: Micro Storm32 (unfortunately I do not recommend this model due to its limited functionality, but it works for this purpose).
Weight: 233g with camera, 157g without

Balancing:
Balancing is mainly done through loosening the bolts holding the arms to the roll/yaw motors and sliding the bolt spacer along the adjustment slot. For the pitch axis a similar thing is done with the pitch cam mount to adjust up and down. To adjust forward and back on the pitch axis loosen the bolts holding the camera frame to the pitch mount and move the camera back as necessary. A spacer between the pitch mount and camera frame may then be necessary. The Xiaomi Yi should balance perfectly on the pitch axis without any adjustment to forward/back. Lens of the camera is closest to the pitch motor.

Different Motors/Parts:
If you are using a GoPro print 'CameraFrameGoPro' and 'CameraBarGoPro'. Ignore the other ones camera frame and bar.

If you use the full size Storm32 controller print the full size Storm32 housing parts at the bottom of the list and ignore the controller housing and controller tube clamp files around the middle of the list.

If you need the design modified to fit a different gimbal motor or part, then let me know! I can modify the design for your needs. No guarantees though as there is only so much you can do without the physical parts in hand.

Revisions:
Isolator Bottom: The vibration isolator bottom has been revised to stiffen it up and improve yaw motor clearance.

Old, obsolete parts are located at the bottom of the parts list. There is no need to print those parts unless desired.

Video shot using this gimbal: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4oZvns_sekI

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

FolgerTech 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Arms: Print with adjustable part of arm down on bed, motor casing pointing up,

Tube Clamps: Printed in two halves, hook part flat on bed. Join halves together with a small brad nail in between to add strength. Print with 'C' part of clamp flat on print bed. Note 2 full clamps are needed for the vibration isolator and 2 for the controller housing.

Camera Bar: Print on side (so the curved part is an arch).

Not wanting to buy a commercial 3-axis gimbal, I struggled to find a 3D printed design that really fit my needs. I wanted something lightweight, compact, and that could fit a Xiaomi Yi yet perform well. After lots of designing and prototyping the first version to be released is ready to share.

This thing is based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:138821 created by Flynn Product Design under Creative Common Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike.

The SCAD file is all my own work, I reverse engineered it from a printed pair of 138821.

The main difference is that I created this model to work with cheap blades from the discount store. Instead of locking the blade from the side and bottom, my version only locks the blade when the tool is on top of it.

Be careful when using this tool. Keep your thumbs in the thumb saddles and your index fingers pinching the other side of the saddles. Keep all parts of your body away from blade. Use at your own risk.

description.text:
it takes a 380 motor the one i used was from a old printer. The inlet will fit directly in to a soda bottle and the output is 8mm od and 6mm id. It will output about 1.7 litres a minute with the 2nd of the 3 blades and that is the only one i tested. It will need grease around the edge to seal it i use lucas oil red and tacky i printed it in pla but i would advise you to print it in abs or something more durable. It is held together by m3 bolts and nuts and i was running the motor at 12v

edit
also i will try and post a video of the pump working in the next couple of days

edit 2
thanks to frankvdh suggestion i have made a new housing that requires no support

edit 3
here is the video of it
https://youtu.be/gwLyB70k8wY

comments.text: thanks for the suggestion i will fix that tomorrow and the bump on the bottom id for the lip on the motor where the bushing sits I  will add a photo so you can see

ipad pro 12.9 x 1 this will just have to hang over the edge due to length/height restrictions
ipad pro 9.7 x 2 These may too
ipad mini x1
kindle fire x1
phone/ipod x 3

i'll update as i test it
Update 1: clips are too flimsy; need to resize

V2: Slimline. No cable clips. Fits Rep 2x bed.12hr build @ 0.2 and 10% infill
Note:Currently strength testing. Possible issue with layer adhesion

V3: Modular. Limited by build volume? Mix and match setup. Just print 2 clips to join them.
Average time 1-2 hours per part
Note: May build usb port box underneath. Clips only stop back and forth movement, not side to side

comments.text: Sure thing!  I've been selling these chiefly made with HIPS.  I currently have red, green, black, and orange.  I'm willing to get other colors. I've also printed them in Alloy 910, they look very nice, but the filament cost is double HIPS, same for nGen.  I have been selling the camera mount, antenna guard, and brace in Alloy 910, just because its more durable (and a small part).  Alloy 910 can be dyed with Rit dye, too, which I do for an added charge.

description.text:
Filament spool mount that bolts to 2 cm extruded aluminum frame.

Don't like that wood crowding your beautiful metal structure? Want to add some color to your 3D printer? Then you've come to the right place. The wood has a terrible coefficient of friction which causes the extruder to work overtime to get filament out of the spool. Well you can solve that problem an add a bit of flare with this excellent piece of hardware.

You don't want the minimum amount of flare do you?

Note: You'll have to scale everything except for the roll by 1000%, was designed in mm for use in cm... oops

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

title: Robo3d R1 Z Axis Bearing Stabilizer

description.text:
So I made a Z Stabilizer that uses a 608ZZ 8x22x7 Shielded Greased Miniature Ball Bearings. I tried to make something different because every z stabilizer i make would always catch the threaded rod and bind it up. I did sand the inside to clean up the stragglers and make it easier to fit the bearings.

Make both of them. I printed them without support at a 25 infill PLA. I used two sided stick pads to mount to inside double sided tape could work to. The right side on mine had more of a gap and was a bit of a pain getting correct gap length but should be good let me know your thoughts.

The Bearings:
http://www.amazon.com/Bearing-Shielded-Greased-Miniature-Bearings/dp/B002BBD6X4?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=od_aui_detailpages02

Robo 3D

title: Tiny Whoop Mini FPV Camera/VTX Mount (Blade Inductrix)

description.text:
Similar to others, I sought to improve the fit of the naked camera (without the plastic case) and make the base and walls thicker.

Update1 : V2 has speed holes to reduce the weight. The standard camera angle is 20 degrees.

Update 2: I've added a 10 degree option, too.

Update 3: Had a crazy Kiwi (Dronewolf) as for a 45 degree option!

Update 4: Added an Ultra-light version.

Available for sale here: www.rockstaralchemist.com

comments.text: On the FX798T the camera does not completely fit on the Ultra-Light version due to a protruding component of the lower right side (from the back). Maybe this issue pertains to my camera only or maybe the mount is too small. I printed mine in PLA with 100% infill.
comments.author: MrToaf

comments.text: It fits in mine.  Not sure where you're seeing the issue.  I took some pictures:
comments.author: MrToaf

comments.text: hmmm. I will try to print again with 20%, what was your shell thickness?
comments.author: RockstarAlchemist

comments.text: 1mm

author: RockstarAlchemist

title: QAV-R Flight Controller Mount for APM 2.6/2.8

description.text: This mount attaches to the QAV-R base plate and allows for an APM 2.8 flight controller to be attached using dampening grommets.

In order for the mount to work, your flight controller must have the enclosure that includes the mounting offsets.

APM 2.8 Flight Controller with Enclosure

author: redhair

title: Kabbalah Pendant
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Second rendering of the Kabbalah, I made. This one is more of a pendant, but you could use it for anything really. I added rings onto it so you can weave different strings through it or put crystals/stones/other decorations into it.

[UPDATE] After a few printing errors, I've troubleshot the model and posted the new updated one, it almost feels as if "multiple forces didn't want this file to be able to be printed" lol

IF YOU PRINT IT, POST YOUR PICS!!!! :D

THIS MODEL IS NOT FOR SALE OR PROFIT. THIS INCLUDES SITES SUCH AS:
EBAY, ETSY, MYMINIFACTORY, PINSHAPE, 3DHUBS, CGTRADER OR ANY OTHER SITE WHERE 3D PRINTABLE MODELS ARE SOLD.

SELLING FREE MODELS ONLY RESULTS IN ARTISTS RELEASING LESS FREE MODELS. HELP KEEP IT FREE

description.text:
I wanted to keep my laptop on the keyboard drawer. The 2 inch side wall always hindered with the cables on the left side. So, i decided to make a wedge shaped laptop. It took me 7.5 hours to print on a standard setting, but it was worth the weight.

After printing, i realized that the front lip was a little short, for some other laptops, so i extended the height by 10 mm and have uploaded the modified files. For more stability, or for larger laptops, you can print 2 of these and place them side by side.

Printer:

QidiTech

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

You might have to rotate the object when you import it in makerbot
I used 123D Design to design this.

comments.text:
You might need two of these for 16 inch laptop. My mac is 13 inch, so I am able to use it with one stand. i don't remember how much filament it uses. A lot will depend on the parameters you use for printing, especially the number of shells and your infill percentage. If you are concerned with the filament use, you can reduce the following parameters:
1) roof and floor thickness
2) do not use raft
3) number of shells
4) infill density

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with Ultimachien PLA at 210C 40mm/s perimeters, 90mm/s infill, 25mm/s on first layer, 0.2mm layer height, and 40% infill for strength, feel free to up it for your needs.

description.text:
A strong corner piece for building frames out of 2020 Aluminum extrusion. Each of the three pieces joined together by the part are contacted by three screws each in a triangular pattern. The part fits into the extrusion's slot for a tight secure fit. The screw holes are for M4 screws with hex socket head caps, there is a 2mm counter sink on each holes. One of the screw holes is for an M6, the hole on the end of the extrusion must be tapped for this.

General Specs:

  • Print at 40% for Strength, PLA is fine
  • Layer height at 0.2mm for screw hole/countersink accuracy
  • M4 Metric Screws with 2mm Countersink
  • Channel slots for tight and square fit
  • M6 Metric screw for extrusion end tapped hole
  • Each Aluminum piece is contacted by three screws in a triangular patter for max rigidity
    UPDATE 1:
    I have added two additional models, one is the same part but the hole for the taped hole of the extrusion is left out. The other model has a cube in the corner and also lacks the hole for the tap as it is unnecessary. I haven't printed them yet but They are nearly identical to the original model, in OnShape I just duplicated the parts and adjusted parameters, Parametric modeling FTW!

Printer:

Maker Architect (Replicator 1 Clone w/ Heatbed)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Printed with Ultimachien PLA at 210C 40mm/s perimeters, 90mm/s infill, 25mm/s on first layer, 0.2mm layer height, and 40% infill for strength, feel free to up it for your needs.

OnShape

Modeled in OnShape, using the extrusion tool and chamfer tool.

description.text: Re-mixed iPhone 5s car mount by guytc to make it fit my iPhone 6s Plus and my Ford Fusion.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/k5wRZcCgQsv

After printing IronAwe's great circle-square i found it hard for my buffalo fat fingers to hold the square, wood dowel and my pencil all at same time. Thought if it had a thumb grip on it, i could push it against the wood while pushing it up to the square. This is the out-come of my thoughts and seems to work well for me on those real small dowels i use.  
Make sure you have "Cool" turned on in Skeinforge and not to scale it down too small.  
Also, if your printer prints tall items with a bit of slope, right after printing while it's still hot and on the build plate, grab a small wood dowel and hold it square against the square edges and hold/push the thumb support square while it hardens. Just a thought.  
Mine printed well, hope you enjoy, Rick.

My first post @ Thingiverse.
Comment below if my idea doesn't work.
P.S: The number of your middle part depends on the number of glues you have.
(x glues require [0.25x] middle parts)

I used Tinkercad to put the handle of thoromyr's Lego Sword onto IonEwes Lego Crystal.

Fastest design-print request I've ever fulfilled: 5 minutes to find the models, 10 minutes to combine them, 10 minutes to print. 25 minutes from daughter's request to finished thing.

description.text: A hand-friendly object formed by the intersection of three mutually perpendicular cylinders.

This makes a nice worrystone for your desk, although it tends to scurry off in an unpredictable direction when dropped. It prints in two halves, with alignment holes for 3 mm filament that hold the parts in position during clamping. Spread solvent adhesive on the flat surfaces and in the holes, insert short lengths of filament, and clamp together. The joint will be (nearly) invisible among all the identical lines forming the layers. The OpenSCAD program also includes a HoleWindage Finagle Constant that slightly enlarges the holes: adjust that and the filament size to suit your printer. The ThreadThick and ThreadWidth parameters should also match the Skeinforge (or Slic3r or whatever) settings. It bounces better with higher Infill ratios: 0.50 sounds hollow, 0.90 sounds "plasticky", and 1.0 probably makes it skitter under your desk. More details and background on my blog:
http://softsolder.com/2011/10/15/thing-o-matic-triple-cylinder-thing/

description.text:
Featured on MyMiniFactory!

Also see The HIVE - Stackable Hex Drawers
The HIVE is a fully stackable version of these modular hex drawers

This is an extension of my Modular Wine Rack.
I noticed my wine rack could also make great stackable drawers.
The hex modules are 75 mm long and 75 mm wide.

More Modular Drawer Systems
  • The HIVE - Stackable Hex Drawers (Interlocking)
  • Modular Drawers 2.0 (Interlocking)
  • Modular Drawers 1.0 (Stackable)
  • Economical Drawers (Not modular)
Find me on:

Update 2/19/2017
I removed the stacking piece because it is a waste of filament compared to my HIVE drawers which interlock. If you need to stack in a honeycomb pattern I recommend you print the HIVE drawers instead.

Update 06/07/2016
Later in the day I uploaded the module with a back and the drawer with a separator.

Update 06/08/2016
I uploaded both the voronoi module and the voronoi module with a back. I also uploaded dual modules.

Update 06/09/2016
I uploaded the voronoi dual modules and the dual modules with a back.

Update 06/15/2016
I uploaded the module stacker. This addition makes for easier stacking.

Update 08/2/2016
I uploaded the wall mounting module with the tab. The tab is reversible so that the module can be mounted from the inside or the outside. I made a special module for mounting with tabs on the inside. It is 3mm taller than the others. I also included another drawer.

Update 09/13/2016
I uploaded a larger module and drawer. 100 mm in height and width.

Printer:

Maker Select V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

100-200 microns

Notes:

Print modules at 102% to compensate for tolerances. If you print as is they will not fit due to expansion of material.

comments.text: Just printed some and the tolerances are not good. The inner diameter of the frames (with the back wall) comes out at 74, 6 or 7 but the outer diameter of the drawer (with separation) is at 75 at their diagonal measures. The module fits inside the stacking piece. The stacking piece has small rectangles that have been extruded outwards and inwards with every other prong. They have also been tested, I have not tested the stacker since it is less efficient

Here are the files to my I-Sore ipod build, Full build is at http://www.instructables.com/id/I-Sore-2000GB-2tb-Ipod
You can check my blog at http://www.jimbone.ca to see the first builds and what I started from as well as my other projects.
These files are for the first ipod that is black and white in the files so you can make your own and the others are examples are ones I have made that still hold the same internals.
This was made in tinkercad so I know if can be improved and hope to do more to it later.
I am trying to work with the rockbox forum to fix the firmware so that I can get the full 100 hours out of my player. only happens if you leave it running nonstop but off and on gives about 50 hours.
I have made my cases using petg plastic that is a bit more durable but I think PLA can handle it as long as you don't drop it or give it a good coat of XTC-3D since that stuff is really strong.
Cable file is to help to hold the wiring back but you can do it with out if you are having problems.
The thicker back was originally for the thicker 2tb hdd but still need to work on it but it helps if you need the extra space to help yourself.
I will have some posted for sale on etsy at https://www.etsy.com/shop/Jimbone if interested otherwise have fun with your build and thrift stores are a great source to find a case for your next I-Sore.

This is a modular bathroom system to hang your shower items from your shower door or square towel rack.

So far, the system includes a Contact Lens holder, a Double-sided safety razor and razor refill holder, a toothpaste and shaving cream holder, and a feminine razor (wider neck) and toothbrush holder.

All holders include an adjustable wire system where you can choose which hole to use to fit your shower rod and/or shower door frame width, from 20 to 55mm.

Requires the use of a stiff wire to hold it. I used a wire coat hangar, but you can choose other sources.

I will be adding different modules as I can think of them, and there is a base plate for you to edit from.

E: New module, Large Toothpaste/Bottle holder, added 06/08/16.
E: New Module, Loofah Holder and Soap Holder, added 07/26/16

Solidworks files included for editing, or have a go at the .stl!

description.text:
BigBox LCD Enclosure.
The standard BigBox LCD enclosure is of course beautiful, but it has some flaws. In this design I improved some (if not all) of them:

  • the opening for the SD card is bigger, with rounded corners, making removal of the SD card easier.
  • There is a hole in the front of the panel, making it possible to (re)adjust the LCD contrast without taking apart half of the printer
  • I've added a hole for the reset button, now you can do an emergency stop without powering off the printer

Some other small improvements:

  • No more screws on the front of the panel, the hex screws are in the inside of the panel mount
  • I've added a bracket that prevents the bending of the LCD PCB when mounting the screws of the LCD panel.
  • A nice printable big knob on the front of the panel :-)

Parts needed:
4x M3 12mm screws for the LCD screen
6x M3 16mm screws for mounting the enclosure to the frame

author: profetec

description.text: My printed filament guide was bad about catching the filament and binding it, because the hole was too small. I realized that the filament only needed to be restricted from side to side, so I combined the two OEM filament guide parts (E12 and E13), and changed the hole to a rectangle in a bit of a "hopper" shape to resist filament binding. Dreadpirate15 greatly improved on this design by turning the filament guide into an insert for the extruder. Unlike my design, it's not able to fall off of the extruder body, so I am now using it full-time. I highly recommend checking it out at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:163991.

comments.text: By far one of the best Printrbot mods in my opinion. It has nearly eliminated all motor stalling, thank you so much!
comments.author: csKonopka

comments.text: Glad to hear that it fixed the problem for you! My Printrbot was CNC milled, did you have trouble with Printrbot's OEM lasercut filament guide?
comments.author: csKonopka

Designer: JC

A tall latte mug that should be easy to print without any supports, but it really depends on how much overhang your printer can handle. However, do not pour drink into your 3D printed latte mug because most printable plastics are not food safe.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I use Flashforge Creator Pro to print this object, using 20% infill (honeycomb pattern) and it came out really well (as shown in the photos attached) without any support materials.

There is space beneath the mug, so I would recommend using support material for that area.

description.text:
Given that I couldn't find a proper layer fan design for my heavily-modified G2s Pro, I took it upon myself to design one.

The fan mount will either take up your Z-axis probe mounting hole, though- though you can put it on the other side of the effector. However, given the heatsink fan location I sacrificed it.

You can print it out of any mid or high-temp plastic (ABS and PETG work equally well, nylon may go soft at too low a temperature though.)

The holes are sized for M4 machine screws, as the plastic is soft enough that they'll self-tap. The pics explain how it's all mounted together.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

G2s Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50% (though you can go higher or lower)

Notes:

Printed in PETG at 240C onto a 60C heated bed with Kapton and hairspray. Adhered perfectly.

Can be made in ABS or any other plastic with a similar glass transition temperature. >50% infill recommended. Supports are needed for the overhangs, no matter how you print it.

After building a MendelMax and seeing the extra stability from using a bearing to hold the bottom of the Z threaded rod we decided to add a similar part for a Prusa Mendel.
We've done testing and it seems to work really great for reducing Z wobble. If you have any suggestions or findings from testing please leave them in the comments.

This mounts similar to the existing structure except for a few changes: -The bottom center horizontal threaded rod needs to be cut shorter to 295mm
-Also the two Z drive threaded rods need to be at least 295mm.
-Two 608 bearings are needed to hold the Z drive threaded rod on the bottom.
-You will need two M8 nuts tightened together on the bottom of each Z threaded rods. This sits on top of the bearing. The clamp is the same Prusa rod clamp used on the Z motor mount. So, you will need two extra rod clamps.

comments.text: Heh, maybe you could just take the original mendel parts which have the z motor mounted at the bottom.  Only problem is there isn't enough room to straight couple the motor shaft to the z-rod, so you have to put the motor upside down and connect it with a belt and a pulley.  I would definitely be interested in some new hybrid sells-prusa z rod ideas.

You don't need anything too special to run your motors from the bottom. I should know, I have my Prusa 'the wrong way up'! However, I use some short NEMA17 motors - Z axis doesn't need much power anyway - an extra bar at the bottom for the motor mount, and the Sells Z-rod clamp at the top. Also, bars at the bottom need to go over the bottom vertex rod. See here: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/709557/Reprap/IMAG0106.jpghttp://dl.dropbox.com/u/709557...
comments.author: chugadie

comments.author: droftarts

comments.text: I suppose ideally you would want a support for the leadscrew that wasn't through the motor shaft, like a motor coupling that took the weight on a bearing with thrust washers each side of it, like in the CNC world. But we're not dealing with particularly heavy loads, and it's not moving most of the time. The advantage with motors at the bottom is that the support the motor leadscrew solidly from underneath, though I haven't done this properly yet.

title: Volume knob box for micro USB DIgispark

description.text:
A volume knob box for the micro USB Digispark (20mm x 18mm). It is made for a rotary encoder with a shaft diameter of 6mm and a shaft length of 15mm. A hole for a 5mm LED is given to illuminate the knob. Proven clam-shell design. You'll need 4 M4 Screws (10mm or 16mm). No nuts required.

I suggest a dark color for the base and white or transparent for the knob.

Digispark offers 4 I/O pins. 2 are required for the encoder (P0, P2), one for the encoder pushbutton (P5) and one for a signal LED (P1).

Supports:

No

Notes:

Only the knob might require additional support if you have problems with bridging. Otherwise the knob.STL already includes a sufficient support-ring which can be pulled off.

Use a "concentric top infill" for the knob to have a nice look.

Software and Installation

A general instruction ca be found on Instructables.com. Preparations for Digispark programming is described on Digistump.com. And the code is found on Adafruit.com.
If grounding the pin D5 performs a reboot of your Digispark you have bought a Chinese rip-off. A fix is described by TheToivonen.

title: Traxxas Ball Joint Arm Assembly Jig

description.text:
FYI for some reason when exported as .STL, Autodesk twisted the part around so use Thingiview to get a good look at the actual STL. Anyway.

This is a rod ball jig for Traxxas 5347 ball joints and 10mm OD CF tube.

YOU NEED TO PRINT TWO OF THESE TO BUILD DELTA ARMS.

You can use this for any length delta arms as long as it uses 5347 ball joints and 10mm CF tubing. Just square them up so the post centers are your delta_arm_length, make absolutely sure they're square, and then the rest goes as follows:

1) Cut your 6 CF tubes to length, they should be damn close but don't HAVE to be exact because of the epoxy putty.

2) Spray some hairspray on the jigs. This way, if the epoxy putty for whatever reason decides to bond, a dip in some warm water will help it release. While you're here, sand the shanks of the ball-joints. These will go inside the rods, and the sanding will help it all bond together.

3) Take a small bit of epoxy putty, form it around the shank of the ball joint, and insert into the end of a CF tube. Repeat on the other end, and press it into place in your jig. Form the ooze into a sort of cap (BUT MAKE SURE YOU DON'T GET ANY PUTTY IN THE ACTUAL SOCKET) so that if it does let go of the inside of the tube or ball joint, it'll line right back up.

4) Repeat step 3 5 more times, and leave it to cure.

5) Once the epoxy putty is cured, press the ball portion of the ball-joints into the ends.

The CF rod I used, cut with a pipe cutter and an X-Acto to clean up the edges.

http://www.amazon.com/ARRIS%C2%AE-Outer-Wrapped-Carbon-Surface/dp/B015Z1RU6U?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s01

The ball joints in question, inserted into the ends and held with epoxy putty.

http://www.amazon.com/Traxxas-5347-Hollow-Balls-Large/dp/B000BOLVJY?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00

description.text:
Try the new Grand Castle Generator, less controls and more unique results.

This customizer code generates countless varieties of castles with plenty of customizable controls. Read on for some tips and guidelines.

If you're new to the Customizer concept, start by hitting the "Open in Customizer" button on the right panel. After you play around with the settings and like what you see, click "Create Thing" to have it generated (takes a while) as an STL file you can download.

You'll be able to control the basic elements for a respectable castle:

  • Building (main structure)
  • Towers (ground rooted, sorrounding the building)
  • Turrets (recursively sorrounding towers / turrets)
  • Island (of course...)

When you start out, most settings are set to random and changing the "random seed" value will mix everything. You can start taming your own castle by moving settings away from "0" or "Random" to specific values.

Keep the details OFF for quickly trying different structures, and turn the details on when you're ready to generate. For non-trivial castles you may get "script time-out" in the preview if you have details on, but they might still generate successfully.

Overall dimensions are affected by several settings, so its easiest to generate what you like and then scale it inside your printing software.

The model is meant to allow for printing without supports (45 deg rule).

Before you click "Create Thing"

  • When you click "Create Thing" your model goes into a production QUEUE and you get to choose "email me when its done". Do it.
  • Producing the model with details could take a long time, and may even fail, since Thingiverse limits the generation to 1h. So you might want to first generate your castle without details, stay in the same window ("return to customizer"), and put another generate with details. This way at least you'll always have the simpler version.
  • If you're printing at a small scale (<4cm height?) or low resolution, you may want to forego details completely.

"Partial Generation" Feature: With this feature you can produce separate STLs for Roofs, Island and structures. This is currently good for rendering (e.g. KeyShot).
It's not optimized for multi-material printing, but if you give it a try let me know.

Finally, I've been itching to make a castle generator ever since visiting Neuschwanstein almost a decade ago, and got reinspired by the brilliant http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:862724

Enjoy!

Write below with suggestions, requests and complaints - I'll try to deliver on future versions.

Those of you into OpenSCAD are invited to develop it further. I've tried to make it clear and useful, and there are some basic algorithms (like for distributing the windows) you may find useful in other projects.
Its up on github: https://github.com/zivbot/castle

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

No

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I've printed a simple version so far (shown), at 75% scale. Normal settings. No special issues. It won me "father of the year".

title: Airplane scale model: AF-01
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This airplane is designed by projectgroup AVEM FERRO from inholland university of applied sciences Delft. The project was to design an utility aircraft which can be used for medevac missions and is able to transport 8 persons (including the pilot). Other requirements were a range of 1200Km, max cruise speed of 450 km/h and should be able to carry a 1000kg payload.

The model has been scaled down to 3,5% of it's original size and a stand has been added so the model can stand on its own.

EDIT: New V2 models are uploaded of the fuselage (romp), engines, tail and the wings. These are made with less 'cuts' and should provide for a nicer end result. They cannot be mixed with the original fuselage or tail etc. The stand and props still match.

The renders are all made by Daan Kaasjager, as well as a work in progress FSX model. The 3D CAD model is made by Emiel Noorlander.

AVEM FERRO group members:
Daan Kaasjager
Jordi Liu
Leander van Noort
Peter Zwarts
Emiel Noorlander
Sidney Vorst
Casper van Veen
Erik ten Oever

To read more about the renderings and fsx the following links are nice:
https://dutcheeseblend.blogspot.nl/2016/06/the-avem-ferro-af-01.html
http://www.sim-outhouse.com/sohforums/showthread.php?100808-The-Avem-Ferro-AF-01&p=1026712#post1026712

Printer:

Home build

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Print everything standing up where possible. Engines standing on the front part, wings on the cross section.

Tips:
Print the wings on a raft to reduce extra thickness at the base and to ensure a flat side.
Print the fuselage 'nose up' on a raft with some extra support. (see pictures)
Print the propellors on a raft with support.

All the other parts are printed straight on the bed.

Depending on your printer the landing gear bays may need to be sanded down a little bit in order to fit the stand in.
All the parts can be sanded a little bit with a nail file, or regular sandpaper. And then glued together with superglue.
