Remark:
In meantime, The power supply(EOS VLT 100-4002) is poorly available and because of this it is difficult to rebuild. 5V 2A are required for the Raspberry and 6..18V, 15Watt are required for the audio amplifier.

Description

This is a music player device with touch screen based on a Raspberry Pi and a Adafruit touch screen display (https://www.adafruit.com/products/2097).

I designed the housing with Freecad and printed it with Ultimaker2.
Additionally I created a mpd client software using python and Qt to have a nice user interface working on the small touch screen with 480x320px screen resolution.
The source code for the user interface will be available at github.com later.

The audio amplifier is a TDA7297 with 2x15Watt. (http://www.pollin.de/shop/dt/NjE1OTYzOTk-/Bauelemente_Bauteile/Bausaetze_Module/Module/NF_Verstaerkermodul_DAYPOWER_VM_TDA7297_15_15_W.html)

The sound quality is better than our kitchen stereo, but don´t expect any sound miracles, the speakers are small. If you turn the sound very silent, you will hear some digital noises from the raspberry or the switching power supply.

The device can be used as internet radio or mp3 player. It is also remotable with your Android or IOS device if you install a mpd client software.

I prepared a detailed description how to install the software and how to build the device.

Warning

There is a DANGER TO LIFE!. The device must be build by skilled people because a internal power supply is used that is connected to AC power.
The power supply may still be charged after disconnection from mains and this causes a electric shock when touched.
You bild this device at our own risk!

Beschreibung in Deutsch

Nachträgliche Anmerkung:

Das verwendete Netzteil, ein EOS VLT 100-4002, ist inzwischen sehr schlecht lieferbar, oder zu teuer. Die Elektronik benötigt 5V 2A für den Raspberry und 6-18V, 15Watt für den Verstärker.

Beschreibung

Dies ist ein Musikabspielgerät mit Touchscreen basierend auf einem Raspberry Pi und einem Touchscreendisplay von Adafruit.
(https://www.adafruit.com/products/2097)

Das Gehäuse habe ich mit Freecad entworfen und mit meinem Ulitimaker 2 ausgedruckt.

Zusätzlich habe ich eine MPD Client Software in Python und Qt geschrieben, damit man eine komfortable Bedienoberfläche für die kleine Bildschirmauflösung von 480x320 Pixel hat.

Den Source code für die Software werde ich später auf GitHub.com bereitstellen.

Der verwendete Audioverstärker ist ein TDA7297 mit 2x15 Watt, den man überall im Internet bekommt. Z.B. hier:
(http://www.pollin.de/shop/dt/NjE1OTYzOTk-/Bauelemente_Bauteile/Bausaetze_Module/Module/NF_Verstaerkermodul_DAYPOWER_VM_TDA7297_15_15_W.html)

Die Soundqualität ist besser als die von unserem Küchenradio, aber man sollte keine Wunder erwarten, weil die Lautsprecher sehr klein sind. Bei sehr geringer Lautstärke sind digitale Geräusche hörbar, die vom Raspberry Pi oder von Schaltnetzteil kommen.

Das Gerät kann als Internet Radio (Audio Streams) oder auch als MP3-Player benutzt werden. Man kann es auch mit Android oder IOS-Geräten über Netzwerk fernsteuern, wenn man eine MPD Client Software installiert.

Ich habe eine PDF-Datei mit einer detailierten Anleitung vorbereitet, die die Installation der Software und den Aufbau der Hardware beschreibt.

Warnung:

Es wird ein internes Netzteil verwendet, welches am Netzstrom angeschlossen werden muss!
Es besteht LEBENSGEFAHR! Der Anschluss von fachkundigen Personen vorgenommen werden!! - Auch nach einer Trennung vom Netz kann das Netzteil noch aufgeladen sein, so dass man bei Berührung einen elektrischen Schlag bekommt.
Der Nachbau dieses Gerätes erfolgt auf eigene Gefahr!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Connect usb cable to 5V (black to ground and red to 5V plus) The other red wire is +12V for the amplifier Wiring the power switch. Fasten the power cable. Connect the raspberry with the amplifier. Solder the 12V power supply for the amplifier. Insert the display into the printed frame. Put the screws into the gaps. Connect the display with the raspberry pi. The red wire is pin 1. The covers for the speaker are coated with nylon fabric of stolen nylon Stockings. The red wire of the flat ribbon cable must be connected to pin1. Connect the audio cable to the amplifier. Connect the audio cable to the raspberry. Almost finished! Tighten the bottom. ... and the back wall.

Install the LCD-Display.

You can find a very good manual to connect and install a LCD-Display on the raspberry.
https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-pitft-3-dot-5-touch-screen-for-raspberry-pi

Install MPD (Music Player Daemon)

Open a Terminal to install software:

$> sudo apt-get install mpd mpc alsa-utils

You must modify the mpd configuration file
/etc/mpd.conf
You will find many manuals how to configure mpd on raspian.

Put your music files into the following folder:
/var/lib/mpd/music

The playlists are stored at:
/var/lib/mpd/playlists

Install Python and Qt4

$> sudo apt-get install python3-pyqt4

Install the CuteMpd software

(Sorry the software is not finished yet, but you can see your playlists and play music.)

Get the source code:

$> git clone https://github.com/huvermann/CuteMpd.git

title: Touchscreen Upgrade for Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text:
I had this for a while, and I actually feels it is quiet practical. So here it is, the touchscreen upgrade to run Octoprint on your Printrbot Simple Metal!

Check out what Octoprint is here http://octoprint.org/

UPDATE:
(25/08/2016) new image based on jessie octopi 0.13.0, compatible with RPi3, bring back user access control, octoprint 1.2.15, touchUI 0.3.4

I actually designed this to fit the 5" Touchscreen LCD by Adafruit:
https://www.adafruit.com/products/1596

The display adapter I use is the DPI TFT Kippah by Adafruit:
https://www.adafruit.com/product/2453

Of course you can use any other adapter, however I find this the best option to be fit inside your Simple Metal frame.
Kippah touchscreen required a micro-usb cable attach on the side and connected to the Pi USB port. You will need a relatively small cable for it to fit inside your frame. In my case I use the pigtail micro-usb cable and take out the plastic case**

The FPC extension cable is handy since you will not mount your pi right behind the LCD:
https://www.adafruit.com/products/2098

And of course for all of this to work, you will need a Raspberry Pi.I recommended to use B+, or RPi2, or even better RPi3 for better performance and power handling (and the on-board wifi adapter).

Optionally, get a WiFi dongle. You don't need this for RPi 3.

If you plan to power your Pi from your printer, I suggest you get a 5V- 3A UBEC:
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__4319__TURNIGY_3A_UBEC_w_Noise_Reduction.html

You need to somehow get the input port to your printer 12V power input (don't take it from the GPIO) and get the 5V output to your Pi micro-usb power input. There are 2-ways to do this:

  1. Get a micro-usb cable, strip down the cable, find the tiny power cable (red-black) and solder it to the UBEC
  2. Get a micro-usb cable and the female usb port (solderable). Solder the usb port to the ubec and plug the micro-usb cable to the port (I did this)

If you plan to connect your RPi to your Printrboard internally (no usb cable hanging outside the frame) then you will need an FTDI adapter:
https://www.adafruit.com/products/284

1. Decide on which system you wanna go with, RPi Model B+, Pi2 or 3, internal powering or external, usb connect or internal serial

  2. Get the required parts!

  3. Print the required parts!

  4. Start the LCD assembly! The printed parts are then glued together. Do NOT glue your LCD to the printed parts as it may damage it!

  5. I use double-sided tape to stick the LCD mount to the frame. Attach the FPC extension before sticking the screen mount

  6. Wiring!! DIY!! Do the UBEC wiring first (if you choose to power the pi from the printer)
    be super cautious with the motor reverse power, i.e. moving the motor while not powered can produce electricity for a short time that will power your RPi. This might corrupt your SD card and require you to reflash your Pi.

  7. If you are using E3D V6, then you can corporate the custom firmware to use serial port on the Printrboard rev F. Download the firmware here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:559657
    The Rx Tx port is located on the pin5 and pin7 on EXP1. You need to connect Rx to Tx of the FTDI adapter, and Tx to Rx. Next you need to wire the ground (pin 14 EXP1) to the FTDI. Connect the FTDI adapter to the Pi USB port, and voila you have serial connection instead of usb!! If it doesn't want to connect then swap the Rx Tx connection, you probably got them swapped.

**I will post detail drawing later with the photo of it. Hope this helps

If you are too lazy or too confused on setting up your Octoprint server for the touchscreen, I provide you with my Pi image:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/4urgrp0eao62dcj/octopi-jessie-lite-0.13.0-kippah-touchscreen-backup.rar?dl=0

THIS IMAGE IS ONLY COMPATIBLE WITH RPI2 AND RPI3

This build is based on debian jessie, so it now support Raspberry Pi 3 as well. You need at least 8GB of micro-SD card, I recommend to use a class 10 card.
Write the image using win32 disk imager (windows only): https://sourceforge.net/projects/win32diskimager/
Or clone using gparted (for linux)

default id: pi
default password: raspberry
default hostname: printrbot

default login profile: printrbot
default profile password: simplemetal

After writing the image, open up the boot drive on your micro-sd card (just like using regular usb thumb drive), open up octopi-network.txt and fill in your wifi ssid and password. Plug in to your pi, then expand your file system using "sudo raspi-config"

There are a few ways to access your print server.

  1. Find out your RPi ip address, then type it on your browser
  2. http://printrbot.local/
  3. My image has avahi installed, which means if you use windows it should come out in the network window. Double click that and open it using your browser.

PS: You should now safely upgrade to the latest version of octoprint and touchUI with this build

the power cord is rerouted since I'm using heated bed on it and the standard power cord that comes with it is way too small to hold the current. I'm using a kind of audio plug with 5-6 pins (can't remember) and based on the spec sheet the factory gave it suits my need. I would probably wire out the 5v rail on the pi with the 5v rail on the ATX PSU later, this way the current drawback from the motors won't power on the pi and corrupt it.

description.text: Schlomorific asked me to create a higher pitch prop. So I created some and also added more blades for higher pitch. This is related to my previous designs for the same topic...

comments.text: I'm trying to increase the speed produced by a Minn Kota EM101 (one of those weird engine mounted trolling motors which we are using in an electric boat project).  We've got an OEM Wedge2 prop, and from talking to a support person at Minn Kota, he says the  top speed of the boat with that motor/prop is about 4-5MPH.  This is what we are getting, but we're running it on a much lighter boat than typical outboard driver powerboat.
comments.author: BrianPalmer

comments.text: Hi Brian,

title: Prusa i3 B MK8 duct V1

description.text: My first thingie for the Prusa i3 B Geetech MK8 extruder. It's a work in progress. It doesn't need an additional fan, just seal with a piece of paper the other side of the heatsink in order to increase air flow out of the fins on the eternal part of the heatsink and down the duct. The fins of the heatsink need to be mounted horizontally, not vertically. This apparently is the latest MK8 model with a plastic feeder (not aluminum).

remixed_from.author: HoffmanEngineering
remixed_from.title: Webcam Bed Mount - Makerfarm Prusa i3v

description.text:
A webcam mount that attaches to the corner of a build plate which allows the camera to remain stationary relative to the Y axis. This design is based on HoffmanEngineering's mount, but resized to fit 3mm aluminium beds.

This mount fits Makerfarm i3v and Pegasus printers, but may fit other printers as well.

I copied HoffmanEngineering's OnShape document and modified his parts for a 3mm bed.

My OnShape document is available at https://cad.onshape.com/documents/5756b3dfe4b0bb3e6d896b18/w/6a92f381d473e79f6eed280d/e/4c38a162ee1c1177b6fdd09c.

title: Thews Drive - A Quick Release Flying Extruder for Delta printers

description.text:
Thews made a new extruder drive last week. I've been testing it and it works great!

Best part about this drive is the quick release and being able to clean off filament stuck in the teeth of the spur drive.

The whole idea of suspending the extruder like that is to reduce the length of the bowden tube. Like this I only need 2.1mm retracts and I don't get any blobbing or stringing anymore.

The stepper motor is a Nema11 with a 27:1 ratio gearbox on it. Can be bought here or from many other places: http://www.omc-stepperonline.com/gear-ratio-271-planetary-gearbox-dual-shaft-nema-11-stepper-11hs120674dpg27-p-133.html

It is designed for 1.75mm. I've just drilled it out and put PTFE to suit 3mm filament and it works great. You will need to put a PTFE liner down into the filament path for smooth operation.

Fully parametric version is available on onshape: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/a3cb8db7b43254e191f1baf0/w/6af71ddfbe1a12a952c95254/e/e7b23ea0ffae0b05dfb65ede

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

doesn't matter

Infill:

90%

Notes:

Just print it so it is strong. You may have to drill a few of the holes after printing. Don't drill out the hole with the hex screw in it. You want this one to stay tight, or else it will move up and down when you retract.
Onshape

I'm running 3mm filament so if you run thinner filament I'm sure you could use a higher speed. It might sound slow but it works beautifully!

1x 6mm long M2 screw
1x M2 nut

I suggest 25% infill honeycomb in ABS, it will weight about 12g.
3 perimeters are good.
the shaft is 3mm (but you can drill it up to 5)

description.text:
This is a tribute to Tim Carlielle's R/C airplane designs.

http://timcarlielle.blogspot.ca/2013/02/how-to-build-and-fly-rc-plane.html
https://www.youtube.com/user/RCexperimental

I'm happy with the shape of the struts, but they are a bit heavy with the metal axles, and the joint seems to act as a fulcrum for flexure. Maybe Loctite Super Glue Ultra Gel will take the load.

I've built most of the pink foam plane. The fuselage is crooked so I'm going to print a thin skin fuselage on a light frame. The wing looks good with one carbon fiber spar. More to come...

Notes:

Aim for lightness with strength. Two shells should be enough. Rotate so the straight edge is down. Use a brim of one layer and 10-15 perimeters to stick the struts onto the build plate.

These struts were printed in PLA. I would prefer ABS, but haven't solved the shrinkage issue yet. The red wheel is an ABS print that didn't quite finish.
File or scrape any rough edges until smooth. Drill out the axle holes to fit your axles. They are 4 mm diameter in the design.
